sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the first part of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece thoroughly explains why we need the API and demonstrates its basic usage.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Šime Vidas)
articles.description: Since the introduction of CSS viewport units in 2012, many of us have been using `width: 100vw` as a way to set an element’s width to the full width of the viewport. But, as Šime Vidas explains in this deep dive, `100vw` does not always represent the full width of the viewport due to differences in how browsers handle scrollbars.
articles.title: New CSS Viewport Units Do Not Solve The Classic Scrollbar Problem

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Part 2 concentrates on the key points from Luis’ framework and practical tips about managing a design system that should be both robust and easy to adopt.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? In this article, Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container and shares a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.
articles.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned With Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Design systems can be of immense help, but failure to adopt them invalidates the hard work that goes into building the thing in the first place! In this two-part series of articles, Luis shares his experience with design systems and how you can overcome the potential pitfalls.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: Starting in March 2024, Interaction to Next Paint will formally replace First Input Delay as a Core Web Vital metric. Learn how the two metrics differ, why we needed a new way to measure interaction responsiveness, and how you can start optimizing the performance of your site now for a seamless transition to the latest Core Web Vital metric.
articles.title: Preparing For Interaction To Next Paint, A New Web Core Vital

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eduard Kuric)
articles.description: Five-second testing is a popular method of usability research used in the industry, yet in essence, its core belief boils down to virtually a superstition. Eduard Kuric looks under the hood at how first impressions are affected by various factors and how UX researchers and product owners can ensure that the user’s first steps can get off on the right foot.
articles.title: Five-Second Testing: Taking A Closer Look At First Impressions (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: Discussing the decisions surrounding JavaScript prototypes, the article by Juan Diego Rodriguez scrutinizes their origin, examines missteps in the design, and explores how these factors have affected the way we write JavaScript today.
articles.title: How Marketing Changed OOP In JavaScript

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Oluwasanmi Akande)
articles.description: Git is designed to assure us that we can track a project’s files at different points in time. But it doesn’t assure us that those files are always safe along the way. For those of you who have dealt with the sinking feeling that you’ve irrevocably deleted and lost files, Sanmi has a couple of approaches that, in the right situations, may help bring them back.
articles.title: Recovering Deleted Files From Your Git Working Tree

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Could there be a better way to welcome the new month than with a collection of desktop wallpapers? We’ve got some eye-catching designs to sweeten up the last few weeks of the year and, if you’re celebrating, to get you in the holiday mood.
articles.title: Cold Days, Shining Lights (December 2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sasha Denisova)
articles.description: In this article, Sasha guides you through crucial processes and factors to achieve a consistent brand presence across platforms. She offers an overview of the entire brand identity process, explores collaboration with UI teams, and provides essential details on the assets required for the successful implementation of a digital brand.
articles.title: Crafting A Killer Brand Identity For A Digital Product

articles.author: Vahe Aslanyan
articles.description: Welcome to this book that teaches you how to innovate as a developer. It isn’t just another step-by-step manual on creating specific products. It’s much more.  I’ve crafted this guide with a focus on equipping you with the mindset, skills, and habits necessary for innovation at any scale –
articles.title: How to Innovate as a Developer – a Roadmap to a Successful Tech Career [Full Book]

articles.author: Yemi Ojedapo
articles.description: Idempotence refers to a program's ability to maintain a particular result even after repeated actions.  For example, let's say you have a button that only opens a door when pressed. This button does not have the ability to close the door, so it stays open even when it's pressed
articles.title: Idempotence in HTTP Methods – Explained with CRUD Examples

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: In the competitive world of software development, acing technical interviews is often considered the key to landing a dream job. However, there's another crucial aspect that aspiring developers frequently overlook – behavioral interviews. We just posted a new course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that provides a guide to mastering
articles.title: Mastering Behavioral Interviews for Software Developers

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Building a complex website is a great way to learn how a bunch of technologies work together. We just posted a 10-hour course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to build a hotel management website using Next.js, React, Sanity.io, Tailwind CSS, and Stripe's payment API. Lari
articles.title: Full Stack JavaScript Course: Build a Hotel Management Site with Next.js, Sanity.io, and Tailwind CSS

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: I'm thrilled to announce that the freeCodeCamp community has been developing a comprehensive English for Developers curriculum. Together, we're going to help millions of non-native English speakers prepare for careers in tech. The trailer for freeCodeCamp's new English for Developers curriculumWhy teach English? For the first 9 years of freeCodeCamp's
articles.title: Learn English for Developers – freeCodeCamp A2 English Curriculum

articles.author: Joan Ayebola
articles.description: In the field of software development, effective communication between different software systems is made possible through the essential function of Application Programming Interfaces (APIs).  APIs allow developers to access and use the functionalities of a particular application, service, or platform. Postman is a powerful and user-friendly tool that simplifies
articles.title: How to Use an API with Postman – A Step-by-Step Guide

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: freeCodeCamp just published a major upgrade to our Scientific Computing with Python certification. You can now learn Python coding fundamentals by building 15 projects – right in your browser. A 1 minute trailer for our newly-upgraded Scientific Computing with Python certificationHere's a full list of the 15 projects you'll build:
articles.title: Python Curriculum 2024 Upgrade – Interactive Python Learning in your Browser

articles.author: Jessica Wilkins
articles.description: freeCodeCamp just launched a major upgrade to our JavaScript Algorithms and Data Structures Certification [https://www.freecodecamp.dev/learn/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures-v8/] . You can now learn JavaScript by building 21 projects! A trailer video for freeCodeCamp's upgraded JavaScript Data Structures and Algorithms CertificationInstead of coding through a series of challenges, you will learn the fundamentals of
articles.title: Learn JavaScript by Building 21 Projects – a Major freeCodeCamp Curriculum Upgrade

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: I'm thrilled to announce freeCodeCamp's Christmas gifts to the global developer community: #1: A new JavaScript Algorithms and Data Structures certification, featuring 21 projects you can code step-by-step right in your browser. It's fully project-based, containing more than a thousand new coding challenges. A 1-minute trailer video for freeCodeCamp's upgraded
articles.title: A Very freeCodeCamp Christmas  – Python & JavaScript Upgrades, English Curriculum, The Odin Project

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: For years, people have asked me when we were going to add The Odin Project to freeCodeCamp like we have with other open source programming resources like Project Euler and Rosetta Code. Well, today I'm excited to announce that freeCodeCamp is bringing the legendary open source Odin Project curriculum to
articles.title: The Odin Project on freeCodeCamp – Interactive Version
